DOCNAME: CASE OF STANDARD VERLAGS GMBH v. AUSTRIA (No. 2)
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , a limited liability company with its seat in GPE , is the owner of the DATE newspaper ORG .

CARDINAL . In its issue of CARDINAL DATE Der Standard published an article in the domestic politics section under the heading “ Gossip mongering ” ( “ PERSON ) . The article , which was entitled “ A society rumour ” ( “ PERSON bürgerliches Gerücht ” ) commented on certain rumours relating to the marriage of PERSON , the then Federal President . The article also appeared on the website of PERSON . It read as follows :

“ If the stories circulating between the outlying district of PERSON and the city centre are to be believed , there is CARDINAL topic of conversation at the moment among the socalled upper crust of NORP society : the marriage of the departing presidential couple PERSON and PERSON [ bold print in the original ] . Rumour has it that not only is he about to leave office , but she is about to leave him . The latter claim has of course set tongues wagging furiously in bourgeois DATE and not - so - bourgeois – circles . People here like nothing better than to be able to express outrage about one of their own .

In addition to the allegedly less - than - blissful domestic situation on the PERSON Warte [ the Federal President ’s residence ] , there has been persistent gossip recently about the supposedly close ties between the First Lady , who is her husband ’s junior by DATE , and other political figures . Head of the ORG parliamentary group PERSON [ bold print in the original ] , for instance , is reported to be close to her ( Scheibner has accompanied the presidential couple on a number of foreign trips ) . PERSON is also said to be well acquainted with the husband of the NORP ambassador ( unsurprisingly , given her post as head of the NORP department of ORG ) .

The fact that the President ’s wife took DATE off recently to organise the move from the official residence to the couple ’s newly renovated home in GPE fuelled further speculation . So much so , in fact , that PERSON DATE never squeamish about putting his emotions on display – had the following pre - emptive statement published in his information bulletin , News [ an NORP DATE ] : ‘ Rumours of a separation are nothing but idle gossip’ he said . He added : As of DATE we will be embarking on a new phase of our life together . Any assertions to the contrary are untrue .

Be that as it may , the people are concerned for the well - being of their President . Apparently , the public information desk of ORG has recently had more callers than ever before enquiring about the state of the President ’s marriage . And more than a few of the callers made their enquiries in the ultra - refined tones of GPE . ”
CARDINAL . The article was accompanied by a picture of PERSON and PERSON Klestil - Löffler , looking in different directions .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON and PERSON brought proceedings under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( Mediengesetz ) against the applicant company , claiming that the article published in PERSON of CARDINAL DATE reported on their marriage and family life and thus interfered with the strictly personal sphere of their lives .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE ORG ( PERSON für PERSON ) ordered the applicant company to pay compensation of MONEY ( ORG ) to the first claimant , PERSON , and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL to the second claimant , PERSON . Furthermore , the court ordered the applicant company to publish its judgment and to reimburse the claimants’ costs .

CARDINAL . ORG , referring to section CARDINAL of LAW , held that the applicant company had reported on the strictly personal sphere of the claimants’ lives in a manner that was likely to undermine them in public . It analysed the contents of the impugned article as alleging , on the one hand , that PERSON intended to divorce and , on the other hand , that she had close contacts with CARDINAL men , thus describing her as a double adulteress and Mr PERSON as a deceived husband . In reply to the applicant company ’s defence that the article merely reported on a rumour , ORG noted that even the dissemination of a rumour could breach section CARDINAL of LAW , if it conveyed the impression that there was some truth in it .

CARDINAL . As to the applicant company ’s request to take evidence in order to show that the rumour had actually been spread at the time , the court noted that in cases concerning an infringement of the strictly personal sphere of a person ’s life , section QUANTITY of LAW excluded the proof of truth ( GPE ) , unless the statement at issue was directly related to public life . Such a direct link would exist , for instance , where a publication reported on the state of health of the Federal President which might prevent him from exercising his functions . However , the state of his marriage did not have any bearing on his capacity to exercise his functions nor did it have any other link with public life .

CARDINAL . NORP In assessing the amount of compensation , ORG had regard to the fact that PERSON was a widely read newspaper and to the considerable degree of insult suffered by the claimants . In addition it noted that it was highly uncommon in GPE to report on ( true or untrue ) details of the private lives of politicians . Having regard to the above considerations and the need to deter other media from making similar publications , a relatively large amount of compensation appeared justified . The difference in the sums awarded was to the fact that the second claimant was described as a double adulteress , while the first claimant was “ merely ” depicted as a deceived husband .

CARDINAL . The applicant company appealed . As a point of law it submitted that ORG had wrongly refused its request for the taking of evidence . In its view the publication was directly related to public life within the meaning of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW . The claimants , being public figures , had made their private life part of their “ marketing strategy ” . Like no other presidential couple before , they had kept the public informed about their marriage , starting with the first claimant ’s divorce from his former wife and his remarriage , to the second claimant . Moreover , the first claimant had relied heavily on family values during his first electoral campaign . He therefore had to accept that the public had an interest in being informed about his private life .

CARDINAL . As regards points of fact , the applicant company argued that ORG had wrongly assessed the contents of the article at issue . Read in its proper context , the article did not state that PERSON actually intended to divorce and even less that she was an adulteress . On the contrary the article rather aimed at exposing the idle gossip propagated in certain upper - class circles . It clearly pointed to the absurdity of the rumour by explaining that the allegedly close ties of the second claimant with Mr Scheibner and with the husband of the NORP ambassador had perfectly unsuspicious reasons . Seen in that light , the article did not even relate to the strictly personal sphere of the presidential couple but made fun of the gossip in bourgeois society .
CARDINAL . As regards the sentence the applicant company claimed that the compensation awards were excessive .

CARDINAL . While the appeal proceedings were pending , Mr PERSON died . By decision of DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings as regards PERSON . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) , on an appeal brought by PERSON ORG ’s estate , quashed ORG decision .
CARDINAL . By a judgment of DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . It confirmed that in the present case , the proof of truth was excluded by section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW . The applicant company ’s argument that the claimants were public figures and had exposed their private and marital life to the public eye like no other presidential couple before was not convincing . While the first claimant had relied on his family life and on his then marriage in his first campaign DATE , his marriage with PERSON had not played a role in his second campaign nor otherwise during his second period in office . Moreover , his second and last period in office had been drawing to a close at the time of the publication . In sum , ORG had rightly found that the publication at issue was not directly related to public life . Consequently , it had rightly refused to take the evidence proposed by the applicant company .

CARDINAL . There was no basis for the applicant company ’s assertion that the article was aimed at unveiling the hypocrisy of the so called upper crust of NORP society or that it described the rumours about the PERSON marriage as absurd . ORG had rightly understood the article ’s contents as conveying rumours about the Federal President ’s marriage as if there was some truth in them .

CARDINAL . Finally , as regards the amounts granted in compensation , ORG found that deterring other media from similar publications was not a relevant criterion . Nevertheless the other considerations relied on by ORG justified the compensation awards .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Scheibner brought proceedings under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW against the applicant company in respect of the electronic version of the article , which had been published on the website of PERSON and in respect of the print version . He alleged that the passage referring to him contained an untrue statement amounting to defamation .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE ORG ordered the applicant company to pay ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL to PERSON as compensation for the publication in the printed version of PERSON and LAW as compensation for the publication on the website . Furthermore , the court ordered the applicant company to publish its judgment and to reimburse the claimant ’s costs .

CARDINAL . The court , arguing along the same lines as in its judgment of DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) , held that the applicant company had reported on the strictly personal sphere of the claimant ’s life in a manner that was likely to undermine him in public . It analysed the contents of the impugned article as alleging that the claimant , PERSON , who was a married man , had a close relationship with PERSON and therefore described him as an adulterer . Thus , his strictly personal sphere was affected . However , it found that the publication did not amount to defamation within the meaning of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . As to the amount of compensation it considered that the insult as regards PERSON weighed less heavily than as regards the claimants in the first set of proceedings . In sum , compensation awards of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL as regards the publication in the paper version of PERSON and LAW for the publication on the website , which was less widely read , appeared appropriate .
CARDINAL . The applicant company and PERSON appealed , whereby the applicant company relied on the same grounds as in its appeal in the previous set of proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant company ’s appeal but partly granted PERSON appeal . It held that the impugned statement also breached LAW , since it fulfilled the objective elements of defamation as defined in LAW . The claimant was accused of adultery , which even in a liberal society was still considered an unlawful and dishonourable act . It considered however , that this had no influence on the amount of compensation to be paid , which was therefore upheld .

CARDINAL . As to the applicant company ’s appeal , ORG again confirmed ORG reading of the contents of the article . It added that the placement of the article in the domestic politics section and its presentation including the picture of the presidential couple supported this assessment . Furthermore , the appellate court noted that the applicant company had not argued before ORG that the publication was directly related to public life within the meaning of LAW of LAW .

CARDINAL . In any case , PERSON , though a public figure , had a right to respect for the strictly personal sphere of his life . Rumours about an alleged relationship between him and the wife of the Federal President had no link with his public functions and responsibilities and did therefore not justify the reporting at issue .

CARDINAL . Once the judgment of ORG had become final , Mr Scheibner brought proceedings under LAW ( ORG ) requesting an injunction ordering the applicant company to refrain from publishing any statement alleging that he had a relationship with PERSON .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE before ORG ( ORG ) , the applicant company entered into a settlement with PERSON undertaking to refrain from publishing any such statement . ORG noted that according to constant case - law , a judgment under LAW had binding effect in subsequent civil proceedings relating to the same facts . It ordered the applicant company to pay PERSON procedural costs .
CARDINAL . ORG judgment was served on the applicant company ’s counsel on DATE . The applicant company did not appeal .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides for the strict liability of the publisher in cases of defamation ; the victim can thus claim damages from him . In this context “ defamation ” has been defined in LAW ) , as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Anybody who , in such a way that it may be noticed by a third person , attributes to another a contemptible characteristic or sentiment or accuses him of behaviour contrary to honour or morality and such as to make him contemptible or otherwise lower him in public esteem shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding DATE or a fine ...

( CARDINAL ) Anyone who commits this offence in a printed document , by broadcasting or otherwise in such a way as to make the defamation accessible to a broad section of the public , shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding one year or a fine ...

( CARDINAL ) NORP The person making the statement shall not be punished if it is proved to be true . In the case of the offence defined in paragraph CARDINAL he shall also not be liable if circumstances are established which gave him sufficient reason to believe that the statement was true . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides a claim for damages in cases of interference with the strictly personal sphere of an individual ’s life . In the version in force at the material time , it read as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) If the strictly personal sphere of an individual ’s life is discussed or portrayed in the media in a way liable to publicly undermine the individual concerned , he or she shall have the right to claim compensation for the damage sustained from the media proprietor ( publisher ) . The amount of compensation may not exceed QUANTITY ; ...
( CARDINAL ) The right referred to in paragraph CARDINAL above shall not apply where :

( i ) the statements comprise an accurate account of a debate held during a public sitting of ORG , ORG , ORG , a regional parliament or a committee of CARDINAL of these general representative bodies ;
( ii ) the statements published are true and are directly related to public life ;
( iii ) it can be assumed from the circumstances that the person concerned had agreed to publication , or
( iv ) the statements were made during a live broadcast , and no employee or representative of the broadcaster failed to exercise proper journalistic care . ”
